title: Enriched Doughs: Adding Fat, Sugar & Eggs
introduction:
So far you've been working with lean doughs â€” flour, water, salt, yeast. Now it's time to add the good stuff: butter, sugar, eggs, milk. These ingredients transform bread from rustic and chewy to soft, rich, and tender.

But enrichment comes with trade-offs:
- **Fat coats gluten strands**, making them slide past each other instead of linking tightly. This creates a tender crumb but means you need to build extra gluten before adding the fat.
- **Sugar feeds yeast** (up to a point), but too much sugar pulls water away from the yeast through osmosis, slowing fermentation.
- **Eggs add structure and richness**, contributing both fat (yolks) and protein (whites).

This lesson teaches you to work with these richer doughs and understand how each enrichment changes the bread.
objective: Understand how fat, sugar, and eggs transform dough behavior and flavor

recipeOptions.whyThisRecipe: At 50% butter, brioche is enrichment taken to the extreme. You'll add cold butter cube by cube to a kneaded dough and feel how it transforms the texture. This is the master class.
A moderately enriched dough (butter, sugar, eggs, milk) that's more approachable than brioche. The filling and shaping add fun to the process.

wrapUp: You've now experienced how butter, sugar, and eggs transform dough. The crumb is softer, the flavor richer, and the fermentation noticeably slower. These are the rules of enriched doughs: more fat = more tender, more sugar = sweeter but slower to rise, more eggs = richer color and structure. With this understanding, you can read any enriched bread recipe and predict how the dough will behave.
